questions.text: First change to occur in the distal segment of cut nerves-
Conduction in which type of nerve fibres is blocked maximally by pressure
In excitable cells, repolarization is closely associated with one of the following events
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Option A (Na efflux): This is incorrect because Na + efflux does not play a major role in repolarization. In fact, during depolarization, Na + influx occurs as sodium channels open, causing the inside of the cell to become more positive. The efflux of Na + is not a significant contributor to the process of returning to the resting potential. In fact, sodium is pumped out after repolarization by the sodium-potassium pump (Na + /K + ATPase), but this happens after repolarization is complete.
  • • Option B (Na influx): This is incorrect because Na + influx is primarily associated with depolarization, not repolarization. During the depolarization phase of the action potential, voltage-gated sodium channels open, allowing Na + ions to flow into the cell, making the inside of the cell more positive. The influx of sodium ions is responsible for the upstroke of the action potential, not for returning the membrane potential to its resting state.
  • • Option D (K influx): This is incorrect because K + influx does not contribute to repolarization. During the action potential, potassium channels open towards the end of depolarization and allow K + to flow out of the cell, not into it. K + influx would actually make the cell more positive and would prevent the cell from repolarizing. Therefore, K + influx is not involved in the process of repolarization.

Neuronal degeneration is seen in all of the following except-
The ‘C’ type nerve fibers are least susceptible to
Fine, irregular contraction of individual fibers called-
Which of the following is not a Sarcolemmal proteins?
RMP is mainly due to which ion?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Option C (Calcium): This is incorrect because calcium (Ca 2+ ) is present in very low concentrations inside the cell, and the membrane is not permeable to calcium ions at rest. Calcium is involved in cellular signaling and excitation but does not contribute to the resting membrane potential.
  • • Option D (Chloride): This is incorrect because chloride (Cl - ) is primarily an extracellular ion and has a relatively balanced distribution across the membrane. While chloride helps in stabilizing the membrane potential, it does not play as prominent a role as potassium in establishing the resting membrane potential.

questions.text: In action potential of nerve the overshoot is:
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Option B (Below zero potential): This is incorrect because the overshoot occurs above zero potential, not below it. During depolarization, the inside of the neuron becomes more positive compared to the resting state, leading to the overshoot, which is above zero.
  • • Option C (Below resting membrane potential): This is incorrect because the action potential overshoot happens above the resting membrane potential, not below it. The resting membrane potential is typically negative (around -70 mV), and the overshoot occurs when the potential exceeds zero, not staying below the resting level.
  • • Option D (Above resting membrane potential): Although the overshoot does exceed the resting membrane potential, this answer is not the most precise. The overshoot refers to the membrane potential surpassing zero, which is more accurately described by option A. The resting potential is negative, and the overshoot goes beyond zero potential, making option A the better answer.

questions.text: The Intracellular potassium concentration is 100meq/mmol and Extracellular potassium concentration is 10 meq/mmol. What will be the equilibrium potential for potassium according to Nernst equation? (AIIMS 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • C1= Higher concentration
  • • C2= Lower concentration
  • • R= Gas constant
  • • T= Absolute temp
  • • Z= Valency
  • • Now 2.3RT/F = 60mV
  • • Hence, E(mv)= 60*log100/10
  • • E= 60mV
  • • Now, Intracellular potassium is less compared to extracellular potassium. Hence potassium will move from ECF to ICF. Hence ICF will be negative compared to ECF. Hence E (mV) for potassium= -60mV
